instruction: Can the Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model trained on a large Mid-Infrared (MIR) soil spectral library be considered superior to traditional methods for determining the exchangeable potassium (Kex) content in soil for optimizing remediation of radiocaesium contamination in agriculture?
Output: Yes. The Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model trained on a large Mid-Infrared (MIR) soil spectral library can be considered superior to traditional methods for determining the exchangeable potassium (Kex) content in soil for optimizing remediation of radiocaesium contamination in agriculture. The related study states that the implemented CNN model leads to a significantly higher prediction performance of Kex compared to the baseline method of Partial Least Squares Regression. The CNN model increases the coefficient of determination from 0.64 to 0.79 and reduces the Mean Absolute Percentage Error from 135% to 31% when a large amount of data (10,000 samples) is available. This indicates that the CNN model provides more accurate predictions of Kex content in soil.
